componenttext: So I wanted to ask about some of the capacity coming on in 2020 is replacing some of the domestic supply, specifically if you look at U.S. steel mill and if you look at [indiscernible] Baytown plate mill. Now I was just wondering if you have any thoughts about how that can affect the market and is Nucor as a supplier in any of those mills on raw materials or semi-finished products.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let's start with the semi-finished product since you asked that question about JSW coming online and U.S. Steel. We have been supplying both of those companies. But as a result of that, we built a pretty good product line of round [indiscernible] th
componenttext: Okay. Let's start with the semi-finished product since you asked that question about JSW coming online and U.S. Steel. We have been supplying both of those companies. But as a result of that, we built a pretty good product line of round [indiscernible] that we can sell to the entire market. And we can we recognize that at least at this point in time, we're being told that we will lose that business in the next couple of years. We have been building the customer base outside of those 2, and we've been securing contracts with other customers. So we're confident that we'll be able to replace the tons from U.S. Steel and from JSW with other customers as they pull their business away from us.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And then -- so the second question I have was regarding the steel downstream business, so steel products. Do you succeeded in having improved profitability there as you had anticipated quarter-over-quarter? But when I look year-over-
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And then -- so the second question I have was regarding the steel downstream business, so steel products. Do you succeeded in having improved profitability there as you had anticipated quarter-over-quarter? But when I look year-over-year, it's still below last year's levels, and I'm just confused as to how to think about that. I -- rule of thumb I had in mind what was when you have rising steel prices generally steel products lag. But in a declining steel price environment, one would think that margins can maybe really be higher year-over-year. So just maybe if you could correct me if I'm wrong about that or how to think about what the right normal profitability is or how to think about what that trend can be going forward.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: When you look at the total downstream -- well, I'm assuming you include tube in that generalization correct?
componenttext: When you look at the total downstream -- well, I'm assuming you include tube in that generalization correct?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm just looking [indiscernible]...
componenttext: Yes. I'm just looking [indiscernible]...

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. [indiscernible]
componenttext: Yes. [indiscernible]

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: So when you look at [ tube ], that's really what's been pulling down the downstream businesses. The tubular business right now -- our tubular business now suffering from some of the same things that we see on the steel side, floated inventories in the ser
componenttext: So when you look at [ tube ], that's really what's been pulling down the downstream businesses. The tubular business right now -- our tubular business now suffering from some of the same things that we see on the steel side, floated inventories in the service centers that resulted in lower orders that, of course, drive our surprise down, of course, drives margin stuff. So this is a -- in our opinion, this is the result of too high of an inventory build during last year and the aggressive destocking that you see not only in our steel products but also in tubes. So that's probably the biggest impact on our downstream business, not from just products we anticipated and not [indiscernible] we did last year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: So potential for that to still normalize at once inventory levels normalize in those end markets, is that what we should think about or any way to think conceptually about what that looks like normally?
componenttext: So potential for that to still normalize at once inventory levels normalize in those end markets, is that what we should think about or any way to think conceptually about what that looks like normally?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that this is a question of what's really driving the reductions in tubular and in our steel. Now overall, we believe that the issue is too much inventory in the system that has to work its way through and that at the time that it goes through
componenttext: Yes. I think that this is a question of what's really driving the reductions in tubular and in our steel. Now overall, we believe that the issue is too much inventory in the system that has to work its way through and that at the time that it goes through. You have to remember when you talk about tubular, 80% of the tubulars are sold through service centers. So there's really impacts -- this issue of inventory really impacts the tubular business. But it's also true of our steel business as we talked about many times in the past. Inventories do not necessarily -- service center shipments do not necessarily indicate what's happening with true and use demand. We believe that end-use demand is still very strong. We see that in our order entry rate for OEMs versus our order entry rate for service centers. When you look at our order entry rate for OEMs, we're actually up in the first half by about 4% compared to the 3-year average. Whereas if you look at order entry for service centers, we're down 14% compared to the 3-year average. So that's a pretty good indicator to us that end demand is still pretty strong. Of course, we talked our customers who are basically telling us the same thing. And I'm speaking in general now both of steel and our tubular products also.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll go to Chris Terry with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And next, we'll go to Chris Terry with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: John and Jim, a couple of questions for me. Just in terms of the volume. You mentioned that second half volumes will be more in line with real demand. Have you seen any marked pickup, I guess, in July in the service center borrowing? And how do we think a
componenttext: John and Jim, a couple of questions for me. Just in terms of the volume. You mentioned that second half volumes will be more in line with real demand. Have you seen any marked pickup, I guess, in July in the service center borrowing? And how do we think about maybe second half on first half of this year and maybe second half on second half of last year?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the general comments, and Jim, you can comment on the year-over-year performance and half -- over half performance. I mentioned earlier that after the first $40 a ton increase in sheet pricing, and we did see a pickup in our orders for our
componenttext: I'll start with the general comments, and Jim, you can comment on the year-over-year performance and half -- over half performance. I mentioned earlier that after the first $40 a ton increase in sheet pricing, and we did see a pickup in our orders for our sheet products, and that came both for our OEM customers but also from our service centers. And we beat with our service centers, we talk about what they'll think is going to happen in the second half that the demand, end demand for their products will be steady. It's still strong. They talk about the need for making sure that they get their inventories completely down, which is what they are striving to accomplish. But one of the things that we're seeing also that should be a good indicator of moving in its early in the game, I don't want to be too overconfident here, but we are cautiously optimistic that we hit the bottom on pricing and on volumes. We see our lead times are beginning to stretch out a little bit. Whenever that's supposed to happen, that encourages the service centers to come back into the market. Now with the OEMs, it's more of a steady-state situation. So after the $40 a ton increase, we believe that, that represented the bottom of the market. Service centers, whenever you see prices start to go up, they come back into the market. So we think that, that bodes well for the second half of the year, and we'll see how it plays out.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: And relative to your question about the second half of this year versus last year, obviously, we don't give guidance for the half year. We're saying third quarter is going to be down because of where margins are at having bottomed recently and what we see
componenttext: And relative to your question about the second half of this year versus last year, obviously, we don't give guidance for the half year. We're saying third quarter is going to be down because of where margins are at having bottomed recently and what we see going forward. But from a volume perspective, we certainly saw destocking begin in the second half of last year and then carry into 2019. And there will always be a seasonal slowdown in the fourth quarter, but we would be -- we would expect right now -- and this is a long shot guess -- that volumes in the fourth quarter of this year should be better than last year because we don't expect to see the destocking component in the fourth quarter. We'll just see the normal seasonal slowdown that we'd expect.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: I think if I could just build on that for a minute because I think it's important to think about what took place in 2018 as related to the 232 and everything that was going on. First of all, if you go all the way back in 2017, with tax reform and deregula
componenttext: I think if I could just build on that for a minute because I think it's important to think about what took place in 2018 as related to the 232 and everything that was going on. First of all, if you go all the way back in 2017, with tax reform and deregulation, that was really a shot in the arm for manufacturing. And frankly, the order rate picked up, demand for steel picked up, and it was growing all through 2017, towards the end of '17, but particularly in the beginning of '18, a lot of our customers were weeding about the fact that when the tariffs came into effect, they were not being able to get the steel that they needed to fill their customers arms. That created somewhat of a panic, both with OEM and with our service center customers. They were convinced that the domestic capacity would not end up to supply all the needs that they have to keep their customers happy. But as it played out, 232 came into effect, the imports did go down, and domestic capacity was enabled, was, in fact, able to start up again and fill the need. But during that time when they were afraid of getting not being able to get the steel, they put their inventories to a very high levels. And of course, domestic capacity came on and we're being settle down, the order rate and pricing returned to more normalized levels, but they maintain this high inventory. At the end of the year, they want to get rid of that overall inventory, they began to aggressively destock. So what happens then, they destock buying -- the volumes coming into the mills go down. Pricing results, as a result, goes down. And the next thing you know, beginning this spiral of, in fact, the aggressive destocking was so intense that towards the end of last year and into the first half of this year, we have service centers selling towards the service centers. So it became a very difficult situation. And as always it happens in our business, we always do things. Now we think that we're getting to the point where the inventories are down before normal levels, and we expect to see more normalized ordering rates in the next quarter.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just one quick follow-up. In terms of the end markets, you talked about the 2/3 that you're cautiously optimistic around. The other  1/3, I assume that is that related to orders, or what is that market or which markets are those specifically that you're s
componenttext: Just one quick follow-up. In terms of the end markets, you talked about the 2/3 that you're cautiously optimistic around. The other  1/3, I assume that is that related to orders, or what is that market or which markets are those specifically that you're still working out?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: We think that automotive is going to be down about 2%, so that's one of the markets that we would say is weakening as we go into the second half of 2019. That said, our market share within automotive continues to grow. So there'll be a small pie, and we'l
componenttext:
We think that automotive is going to be down about 2%, so that's one of the markets that we would say is weakening as we go into the second half of 2019. That said, our market share within automotive continues to grow. So there'll be a small pie, and we'll have a larger piece of that small pie. So the impact will be less [indiscernible] and others in our space. 
Another one that I remember being looking [indiscernible] that was down would be power transmission. There's a whole bunch of power transmission projects that were wrapped up at the end of 2018. So power transmission is an industry that we expect to be down also. Agricultural will be down a little bit as we see going forward into the second half of this year also.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll go to Matt Korn with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And next, we'll go to Matt Korn with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: So earlier this week, the White House announced a revision to these by American requirements. I was wondering how much, if any potential incremental effect, do you see from these changes? I asked because our understanding have been that many public projec
componenttext: So earlier this week, the White House announced a revision to these by American requirements. I was wondering how much, if any potential incremental effect, do you see from these changes? I asked because our understanding have been that many public projects already have very high thresholds from melt and [indiscernible] steel, but the administration appears to believe that there were loopholes that limited the effect of those rules. So I'm wondering what your view is.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, there was some loopholes in there. We're pleased to see those loopholes being closed. And you're right, a lot of those regulations already were in place, and it was by American. And we wanted to make sure we did stress the point that this was by Ame
componenttext: Well, there was some loopholes in there. We're pleased to see those loopholes being closed. And you're right, a lot of those regulations already were in place, and it was by American. And we wanted to make sure we did stress the point that this was by American [indiscernible] melted, poured and rolled in the United States. So we made -- we took a little bit of the loophole away from that, that was excessive. So in general, we'll see some impact. We do supply to the militaries particularly out of the plate group and out of our [ SBQ ] group. So it's a positive impact, but it is not a major impact.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then to continue as we kind of go around the product groups here. There's been a lot of focus on hot-rolled coil, some focus on downstream. What's happening in the plate market in your view? Your volumes are off, the prices there are off, they'v
componenttext: Okay. And then to continue as we kind of go around the product groups here. There's been a lot of focus on hot-rolled coil, some focus on downstream. What's happening in the plate market in your view? Your volumes are off, the prices there are off, they've dropped to the 7 50 level. Is that 2-way function pronounced destocking? Or is there true demand challenges occurring for that particular product?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Ths 2 impacts that have occurred on plate. First of all, you need to think about the weather conditions that we endure during in the first half of this year, particularly in the first quarter. On the plate products, they want to bridges and so forth, proj
componenttext: Ths 2 impacts that have occurred on plate. First of all, you need to think about the weather conditions that we endure during in the first half of this year, particularly in the first quarter. On the plate products, they want to bridges and so forth, projects that you have to have good weather in order to be able to proceed. So there's a lot of products are on the books, but we haven't been able to simply because of the extreme weather conditions. The other impact is, as you mentioned, aggressive destocking. Just as we said with the products earlier with tubular and with sheet products, the same occurred with plates. Inventories levels got way too high at the end of 2018, and we began the destocking program. A little bit of a time delay on that or simply because of plate tends to trail hot band by about 2 months, 3 months, in terms of buying the pricing mix. So it's a little bit of a time delay. But basically, the same scenario played out in plate that we described earlier.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019

componenttext: And next, we'll go to Phil Gibbs with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

componenttext: I was reading last night that one of your mill competitors in the North American sheet market [indiscernible] has formally asked these U.S. mills suppliers for concessions and price cuts. Question is, are you either seeking pricing concessions from your mill suppliers or seeing any softness in inputs like electrodes and refractories, alloys or mill services?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, electrodes, we can talk about it in a minute because that's the more specific issue, and we do see price going down in electrodes a little bit, about 7% this year over last year, but that's a very specific issue. There was a runoff in electrodes ove
componenttext: Well, electrodes, we can talk about it in a minute because that's the more specific issue, and we do see price going down in electrodes a little bit, about 7% this year over last year, but that's a very specific issue. There was a runoff in electrodes over the last couple of years that was unsustainable, and we're seeing the [indiscernible] markets go down. But in general, I'll respond to your question. First of all, Nucor is a high integrity company, [indiscernible] the contracts we have and we will not go out in demand any price reductions on contract that we have signed in the current [indiscernible] in place. That said, if our suppliers do, in fact, offer our competitors their pricing, we will go and talk to them about that. We will not demand it, but what we might find is largest steel producer in the United States, we buy a whole lot more everything and anyone else. And if they treat us any differently than our competition, we'll remember that. When those contracts that we have come to an end, we can talk about who we do business with in 2020. Does that answer your question?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Absolutely. And in terms of some of the stuff that was more the others things that were impacted by, I think, the China supply side issues like refractories and alloys, what are you seeing there?
componenttext: Yes. Absolutely. And in terms of some of the stuff that was more the others things that were impacted by, I think, the China supply side issues like refractories and alloys, what are you seeing there?

componenttext: Refractories, they're still pretty high. We haven't seen much of a reduction in that. Alloys are still wanting pretty high, not quite up to the 2018 levels because just like everything else with steel, unless steel we're producing, the less alloys we need, unless refactoring needs to be replaced. So the volumes go down and pricing comes down a little bit, that's more volume related than anything else.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: It's hard to project when you -- right now, as we mentioned a couple of times, we are in a transition. We're in the cusp of a transition from a situation of [indiscernible] destocking to more normalized order entry rate from our service centers. Not being
componenttext:
It's hard to project when you -- right now, as we mentioned a couple of times, we are in a transition. We're in the cusp of a transition from a situation of [indiscernible] destocking to more normalized order entry rate from our service centers. Not being a service center ourselves, we don't know just exactly where those inventories are. Rather say we know exactly what can happen when volumes going into the third quarter, I would say that we're going to transition. How quickly it ramps back up, we'll determine how our third quarter volumes look relative to our second quarter. 
I think the important point to remember is this. We are seeing the transition and this holding back up. We see lead times expanding, and we see -- and really important point here that allows me to sleep easily at night is that our end demand, our end demand is still very strong and usual demand remains very strong. If we didn't see that to our OEM customers, I'll be a whole lot more worried about what rest of the year was going to look like than I am right now.

componenttext:
Thank you, David. Well, I'll close by signing off by saying again, I want to express our appreciation to our shareholders. We value your contribution and capital investment in our company, and we will treat it with great care. I want to say thank you to our customers. We're building our capabilities to better serve you, and we believe that together, we can build powerful partnerships and powerful results. And finally, to my Nucor teammates, thank you for what you're doing for Nucor every day. And most importantly, thank you for doing it safely.
Thanks for your interest in Nucor. Have a great day.

componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation Second Quarter of 2019 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
Certain statements made during this conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, believe, anticipate and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify those forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available.
Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future events will not affect their accuracy. More information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in Nucor's latest 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Qs, which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's websites. The forward-looking statements made in this conference call speak only as of this date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
For opening remarks and introductions, I'd like to turn the call over to Mr. John Ferriola, Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and President of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call and for your interest in Nucor. Other members of Nucor's executive team are also on the call today, including Jim Frias, our Chief Financial Officer; Craig Feldman, responsible
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our second quarter earnings call and for your interest in Nucor. Other members of Nucor's executive team are also on the call today, including Jim Frias, our Chief Financial Officer; Craig Feldman, responsible for Raw Materials; Ladd Hall, responsible for Sheet Products; Ray Napolitan, responsible for Engineered Bar Products; MaryEmily Slate, responsible for Tubular Products; Dave Sumoski, responsible for Merchant Bar and Rebar Products; Leon Topalian, responsible for Beam and Plate Products; and Chad Utermark, responsible for Fabricated Construction Products. 
My remarks will be brief this afternoon as we covered a lot of this material at our recent Investor Day event. Thank you to everyone who participated either in person or via the webcast. And for those who could not join us, the recording of the event and the slide presentation are available at nucor.com.
Before we discuss our second quarter earnings, I would like to thank our teammates for continued excellent safety performance. Safety is the #1 priority for everyone on the Nucor team, and we continue to work to improve at it, identifying and mitigating risks and changing behaviors to achieve our goal of 0 incidents at every Nucor facility. 
Turning now to our performance in this quarter. Our financial results were lower than our expectations at the start of the quarter. Unusually wet weather and aggressive supply chain destocking impacted mill order rates in the first half of 2019.
We have seen lower volumes during the first half of this year, resulting in a more challenging price environment. However, real demand for our products remained strong in key end-use markets. We see healthy conditions in end-use markets that typically account for more than 2/3 of our steel shipments. For this reason, we are cautiously optimistic that pricing has bottomed on most of our products and that volumes should be more closely aligned with real end-use demand in the second half of the year.
We all know that the steel industry is cyclical and we have built our business model around that reality with our low and highly variable cost structure and our diversified product portfolio. 
Our performance in the first half of the year benefited from meaningful year-over-year earnings gains in our plate, MBQ, rebar, joist and deck, metal buildings and pilings distribution businesses, once again highlighting the benefits of our diversified product mix.
Our strategy to increase market share in automotive applications also continues to bear fruit. We are currently shipping into this market at an annual rate of about 1.6 million tons. 
Further, we were recently named Supplier of the Year by General Motors. We are the first EAF-based steel producer to receive this recognition. It's a tremendous testament to our team and further evidence of our success, moving up the value chain and gaining market share in many value-added applications.
As we have previously discussed, we have several investment projects coming online this year, and I want to update you on this status. In our Sheet Group, we continued to ramp up production of our new Specialty Cold Mill at Nucor Steel Arkansas, and we have been pleased with the performance. This project will allow us to produce higher-valued products, especially in high-strength steels, and it will differentiate Nucor Steel Arkansas from its competitors. We are currently in trials for value-added applications, and customer acceptance has been excellent to this point.
We are targeting to have as much as 20% of the new mills capacity booked with contract customers by the year-end. We expect to continue adding contract volumes at the mill as 2020 progresses. 
In Kentucky, Nucor Steel Gallatin has begun commissioning its new galvanizing line and test running coils to verify the functionality of the line. Production of pickled and oiled coils have started this month and will be followed by production of galvanized coils in August. With 500,000 tons of annual capacity, this 72-inch galvanizing line will be the widest hot-rolled galvanizing facility in North America. Gallatin is now positioned to supply the underserved Midwest heavy gauge hot band galvanize market. The new line will enable us to grow our automotive applications, to include frames, control arms, supports and brackets. Our commercial teams are excited to have these new capabilities in our Sheet Mill Group, to serve both new and existing customers. 
The last project in our Sheet Mill Group I would like to mention is our joint venture with JFE Steel in Mexico. We are on track for a start-up of the galvanizing line later this year, and we look forward to serving automotive customers in Mexico.
In the Bar Mill Group, our Marion, Ohio bar mills new in-line rolling mill is starting up in the third quarter. Marion's new reheat furnace, which we installed last year, is reducing our natural gas consumption by about 1/4. In late 2019 or early 2020, Marion will also install Quench and Tempering equipment to reduce alloy costs at the melt shop. The upgrades significantly improved Marion's efficiency and strengthens its leadership position in the regional rebar market. 
2 other projects in our long products group are on track for start-ups later this year, the merchant bar product expansion at our mill in Illinois and the first of our new rebar micromills, which is located in Sedalia, Missouri. In all, we have 10 significant organic investments in various stages of development, representing a total capital investment of approximately $3.5 billion that will deliver long-term profitable growth to our shareholders. 
As I have made clear on several occasions, we are not simply adding tons to get bigger. These projects target to find market objectives and opportunities to generate higher profits and reduce volatility through the cycle. They also expand our product portfolio so that we will be able to offer our customers more solutions to meet their toughest challenges. 
The U.S. steel industry continues to benefit from effective trade enforcement. Through May of 2019, total and finished steel imports declined by 12% and 18% from last year's levels. In the last 12 months, approximately 6 million fewer tons of imported steel have come in to the U.S. market. The decrease in imports reflects the cost competitiveness of our domestic steel industry and the success of our industry's ongoing efforts to see that the rules of trade are enforced.
Recent findings by the U.S. Department of Commerce provide further evidence that our industry, our government and our customers understand the importance of acting to keep on fairly traded steel and steel products from distorting the U.S. market.
On July 2, the U.S. Department of Commerce issued its preliminary circumvention determination on imports of galvanized and coal-rolled sheet steel from Vietnam manufactured with hot-rolled or coal-rolled substrate from South Korea and Taiwan. Congress found that the steel went through minor modifications in Vietnam to avoid appropriate restrictions that have been imposed on imports from South Korea and Taiwan. The imports of these products from Vietnam must now pay duties of more than 400%. It is vitally important that our government stop these and similar illegal trend shipments meant to avoid trade duties, and we are glad that they have taken such a strong action. 
On July 8, the U.S. Department of Commerce also issued a preliminary countervailing duty determination on imports of fabricated structural steel from China and Mexico, and duties have been applied to imports from both countries. This ruling shows that the government is not only concerned about unfair trade practices in raw steel but also in downstream products. Rules-based trade is a critical underpinning to the continued success of our customers, Nucor and the U.S. economy, and we are pleased that the Department of Commerce continues to take action on individual trade cases. 
Jim Frias will now provide more specific detail about our second quarter performance as well as our outlook for the remainder of this year. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. Nucor reported second quarter of 2019 earnings of $1.26 per diluted share. Earnings from our steel mills segment were lower due primarily to reduced shipments to our service center customers, reflecting their caution with respect to inventor
componenttext:
Thanks, John. Nucor reported second quarter of 2019 earnings of $1.26 per diluted share. Earnings from our steel mills segment were lower due primarily to reduced shipments to our service center customers, reflecting their caution with respect to inventory levels and order rates in a weakening price environment. Earnings from our steel products segment improved in the second quarter, in line with our expectations. Strong nonresidential construction markets, along with increased productivity from our rebar fabrication and metal buildings businesses, were the primary factors. Results from our raw materials segment were slightly better than we anticipated.
It is worth noting that our second quarter results included $20.5 million of pre-operating and start-up costs related to strategic investment projects compared with $19.6 million in the first quarter of 2019 and approximately $6 million in the year ago quarter. 
First half 2019 cash provided from operations was approximately $1.2 billion, up from about $870 million for the year ago period. Inventories and receivables were a source of approximately $400 million in the first half, reflecting consistent working capital management in a declining price environment.
Our capital spending accelerated in the second quarter and totaled $650 million so far this year. We have received our permits for the Gallatin expansion, so between that and other projects that we have in our pipeline, we expect to increase CapEx further in the second half and approach our budgeted amount of approximately $1.8 billion for the full year. 
With respect to cash returned to shareholders during the second quarter, we paid dividends of $123 million and stock repurchases totaled $125 million. Thus far, in 2019, we returned 50% of our net income to our shareholders while also investing for long-term profitable growth. We ended the quarter with $1.4 billion of cash on hand. 
Nucor's financial condition remains strong. With total debt outstanding of $4.2 billion, our gross debt-to-capital ratio was 28% at the end of the second quarter. Our $1.5 billion unsecured revolving credit facility remains undrawn and does not mature until April of 2023. Our next material debt maturity is in 2022 for approximately $600 million. 
Now turning to the outlook. Earnings for the third quarter of 2019 are expected to be lower than the second quarter. Inventory destocking, especially by service center customers, has led to declining results year-to-date in our muted expectations for the next quarter. While we are encouraged by recent upturns in the prices for flat-rolled steel products and as John mentioned, we do continue to see healthy demand for our major end-use markets. We've finished the second quarter with much lower margins in sheet and plate steel and believe that margin recovery could take some time. We therefore expect weaker linked quarter performance in the steel mills segment again, primarily reflecting reduced margins for both sheet and plate steel. However, we do expect that service center customers will resume more normal buying patterns in the third quarter. 
The steel products segment is expected to achieve further profitability improvement in the third quarter over the second quarter. Nonresidential construction activity remains strong, and we believe some incremental demand has likely shifted to later in the year due to difficult weather conditions during the first several months of 2019. Recent initiatives to improve the performance of our rebar fabrication and metal building businesses are also expected to continue to favorably impact results for the steel products segment. The performance of our raw materials segment is expected to decline in the third quarter compared to the second quarter due to further margin pressure at our direct reduced iron ore DRI plants.
In addition, later this quarter, we will begin our planned 65-day outage at Nucor Steel Louisiana to complete major enhancements to the physical plant. 
Thank you for your interest in our company. I will now turn the call back over to John.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Before we take your questions, I would like to acknowledge a significant milestone that Nucor teammates at our Darlington, South Carolina bar mill recently celebrated. As many of you know, Darlington is the first steel mill Nucor built. Back
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Before we take your questions, I would like to acknowledge a significant milestone that Nucor teammates at our Darlington, South Carolina bar mill recently celebrated. As many of you know, Darlington is the first steel mill Nucor built. Back in the mid-1960s, our Founder, Ken Iverson, decided that Nucor needed to be able to supply its own steel for its joist operations in Florence, South Carolina.
Nucor selected EAF technology for Darlington and took the first step in leading the transformation of the domestic steel industry that has occurred over the past 50 years. We celebrated this 50-year run at Darlington on June 26. 
Darlington continues to be a strong contributor to Nucor's profitability and a valued member of its community. We look forward to another 50 years of success at Darlington. 
In closing, I would like to say thank you to our more than 26,000 teammates for the way you execute our strategy, and thank you for the work that you do every day to build a safer and more profitable Nucor. I'd also like to say thank you to our customers. We appreciate the trust you place in Nucor, and we will continue to do our very best to earn it with every order. And finally, thank you to our investors for entrusting us with your valuable capital. 
We would now be happy to answer your questions. Operator?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019

componenttextpreview: We built some inventory, but we have -- one of the great things about our raw materials strategy overall is the flexibility of it. And we have the DJ Joseph team that's been able to go, frankly, globally to secure any scrap that we need, prime or obsolete
componenttext: We built some inventory, but we have -- one of the great things about our raw materials strategy overall is the flexibility of it. And we have the DJ Joseph team that's been able to go, frankly, globally to secure any scrap that we need, prime or obsolete. We have great sources of [ HPI ] that we can bring in, again through David J. Joseph. And we have great sources of pig iron that we can bring in. So we are not at all concerned about being able to get the virgin iron units that we need to maintain [ in producing ] the ultrahigh-strength steels during this period of outage from the DRI plants.

componenttext: Well, there's been 2 that have been introduced. So the first one was -- maybe it was 3 weeks ago, 3 weeks ago, and we were able -- it's $40. The second one was just about a week ago, and it's really too early to tell too much about how much we'll get of that $40, but the initial week looks encouraging. We're also encouraged by the fact that as a result of these increases, we've seen an increase in the volume of our orders coming in also, so all 3 of our hot band coal-rolled and galvanized products.

componenttext: So I wanted to ask about some of the capacity coming on in 2020 is replacing some of the domestic supply, specifically if you look at U.S. Steel's Fairfield mill and if you look at JSW's Baytown plate mill. Now I was just wondering if you have any thoughts about how that can affect the market and if Nucor is a supplier on any of those -- to any of those mills on raw materials or semi-finished products.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let's start with the semi-finished product since you asked that question about JSW coming online and U.S. Steel. We have been supplying both of those companies. But as a result of that, we built a pretty good product line of round billets and blooms
componenttext: Okay. Let's start with the semi-finished product since you asked that question about JSW coming online and U.S. Steel. We have been supplying both of those companies. But as a result of that, we built a pretty good product line of round billets and blooms that we can sell to the entire market. And we recognize that at least at this point in time, we're being told that we will lose that business in the next couple of years. We have been building a customer base outside of those 2, and we've been securing contracts with other customers. So we're confident that we'll be able to replace the tons from U.S. Steel and from JSW with other customers as they pull their business away from us.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. All right. So the second question I had was regarding the steel downstream business, so steel products. You succeeded in having improved profitability there as you had anticipated quarter-over-quarter, but when I look year-over-year,
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. All right. So the second question I had was regarding the steel downstream business, so steel products. You succeeded in having improved profitability there as you had anticipated quarter-over-quarter, but when I look year-over-year, it's still below last year's levels and I'm just confused as to how to think about that. I -- rule of thumb I had in mind was that when you have rising steel prices, generally, steel products lag. But in a declining steel price environment, one would think that margins can maybe be higher year-over-year. So just maybe if you could correct me if I'm wrong about that or how to think about what the right normal profitability is or how to think about what that trend can be going forward.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So when you look at tube, that's really been what's pulling down the downstream business. The tubular business right now -- our tubular business right now is suffering from some of the same things that we see on the steel side, bloated inventories in
componenttext: Yes. So when you look at tube, that's really been what's pulling down the downstream business. The tubular business right now -- our tubular business right now is suffering from some of the same things that we see on the steel side, bloated inventories in the service centers that resulted in lower orders that, of course, drives the price down, that, of course, drives the margins down. So this is a -- in our opinion, this is the result of too high of an inventory build during last year and the aggressive destocking that you see, not only in our steel products, but also in tubes. So that's probably the biggest impact on our downstream business, not from just the products we anticipated and not from just the ones we did last year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: So potential for that to still normalize at once inventory levels normalize in those end markets, is that what we should think about, or any way to think conceptually about what that looks like normally?
componenttext: So potential for that to still normalize at once inventory levels normalize in those end markets, is that what we should think about, or any way to think conceptually about what that looks like normally?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that this is a question of what's really driving the [ blind ] reductions in tubular and in our steel. Now overall, we believe that the issue is too much inventory in the system that has to work its way through and at the time that it goes th
componenttext: Yes. I think that this is a question of what's really driving the [ blind ] reductions in tubular and in our steel. Now overall, we believe that the issue is too much inventory in the system that has to work its way through and at the time that it goes through. You have to remember, when you talk about tubular, 80% of the tubulars are sold through service centers. So this really impacts -- this issue of inventory really impacts the tubular business. But it's also true of our steel business as we talked about many times in the past. The inventories do not necessarily -- service center shipments do not necessarily indicate what's happening with true end-use demand. We believe that end-use demand is still very strong. We see that in our order entry rate for OEMs versus our order entry rate for service centers. When you look at our order entry rate for OEMs, we're actually up in the first half by about 4% compared to the 3-year average. Whereas if you look at order entry for service centers, we're down 14% compared to the 3-year average. So that's a pretty good indicator to us that end demand is still pretty strong. Of course, we talk to our customers who are basically telling us the same thing, and I'm speaking in general now both of steel and our tubular products also.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll go to Chris Terry with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And next, we'll go to Chris Terry with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: John and Jim, a couple of questions from me. Just in terms of the volume, you mentioned that second half volumes will be more in line with real demand. Have you seen any marked pickup, I guess, in July in the service center borrowing? And how do we think
componenttext: John and Jim, a couple of questions from me. Just in terms of the volume, you mentioned that second half volumes will be more in line with real demand. Have you seen any marked pickup, I guess, in July in the service center borrowing? And how do we think about maybe second half on first half of this year and maybe second half on second half of last year?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the -- with just general comments, and Jim, you can comment on the year-over-year performance and half-over-half performance. I mentioned earlier that after the first $40 a ton increase in sheet pricing, we did see a pickup in orders for o
componenttext: I'll start with the -- with just general comments, and Jim, you can comment on the year-over-year performance and half-over-half performance. I mentioned earlier that after the first $40 a ton increase in sheet pricing, we did see a pickup in orders for our sheet products, and that came from both our OEM customers, but also from our service centers. When we meet with our service centers, we talk about what they'll think is going to happen in the second half, that the demand, the end demand for their products will be steady. It's still strong. They talk about the need for making sure that they get their inventories completely down, which is what they, too, were striving to accomplish. But one of the things that we're seeing also, that it should be a good indicator of moving in and it's early in the game. So I don't want to be too overconfident here, but we are cautiously optimistic that we've hit the bottom on pricing and on volumes. We see our lead times are beginning to stretch out a little bit. Whenever that starts to happen, that encourages the service centers to come back into the market. Now with the OEMs, it's more of a steady-state situation. So after the $40 a ton increase, we believe that, that represented the bottom of the market. Service centers, whenever you see pricing start to go up, they come back into the market. So we think that, that bodes well for the second half of the year, and we'll see how it plays out.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: And relative to your question about the second half of this year versus last year, obviously, we don't give guidance for the half year. We're saying third quarter is going to be down just because of where margins are at, having bottomed recently, and what
componenttext: And relative to your question about the second half of this year versus last year, obviously, we don't give guidance for the half year. We're saying third quarter is going to be down just because of where margins are at, having bottomed recently, and what we see going forward. But from a volume perspective, we certainly saw destocking begin in the second half of last year and then carry into 2019. And there will always be a seasonal slowdown in the fourth quarter, but we would be -- we would expect right now, and this is a long shot guess, that volumes in the fourth quarter of this year should be better than last year because we don't expect to see the destocking component in the fourth quarter, we'll just see the normal seasonal slowdown that we'd expect.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: I think if I can just build on that for a minute because I think it's important to think about what took place in 2018 as we relate it to the 232 and everything that was going on. First of all, if you go all the way back to 2017, with tax reform and dereg
componenttext:
I think if I can just build on that for a minute because I think it's important to think about what took place in 2018 as we relate it to the 232 and everything that was going on. First of all, if you go all the way back to 2017, with tax reform and deregulation, that was really a shot in the arm for manufacturing. And frankly, the order entry rate picked up, demand for steel picked up, and it was growing all through 2017. Towards the end of '17, but particularly in the beginning of '18, a lot of our customers were reading about the fact that when the tariffs came into effect, we would not -- they would not be able to get the steel that they needed to fill their customers' orders. That created somewhat of a panic, both with the OEM and with our service center customers. They were convinced that the domestic capacity would not be enough to supply all the needs that they had to keep their customers happy. 
But as it played out, 232 came into effect, the imports did go down, and domestic capacity was enabled, was, in fact, able to start up again and fill the need. But during that time when they were afraid of getting -- not being able to get the steel, they put their inventories to very high levels. And of course, domestic capacity came on, everything settled down, the order rate and pricing returned to more normalized levels, but they've maintained this high inventory. At the end of the year, they'd want to get rid of that overblown inventory and they began to aggressively destock. So what happens then, okay, they destock volume. All the volumes coming into the mills go down. Pricing results, as a result, goes down. And the next thing you know, we get into this spiral of -- in fact, the aggressive destocking was so intense that towards the end of last year and into the first half of this year, we had service centers selling to other service centers. So it became a very difficult situation. And as always happens in our business, we overshoot things. Now we think that we're getting to the point where the inventories are down before normal levels, and we expect to see more normalized ordering rates in the next quarter.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just one quick follow-up. In terms of the end markets, you talked about the 2/3 that you're cautiously optimistic around. The other 1/3, I assume that -- is that related to orders, or what is that market or which markets, so those specifically that you're
componenttext: Just one quick follow-up. In terms of the end markets, you talked about the 2/3 that you're cautiously optimistic around. The other 1/3, I assume that -- is that related to orders, or what is that market or which markets, so those specifically that you're still working out?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: We think that automotive is going to be down about 2%, so that's one of the markets that we would say is weakening as we go into the second half of 2019. That said, our market share within automotive continues to grow. So there'll be a small pie, and we'l
componenttext:
We think that automotive is going to be down about 2%, so that's one of the markets that we would say is weakening as we go into the second half of 2019. That said, our market share within automotive continues to grow. So there'll be a small pie, and we'll have a larger piece of that small pie. So the impact will be less felt by Nucor and others in our space. 
Another one that I remember being -- looking from a chart that was down would be power transmission. There was a whole bunch of power transmission projects that were wrapped up at the end of 2018. So power transmission is an industry that we expect to be down also. Agriculture will be down a little bit as we see it going forward into the second half of this year also.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019

componenttext: And next, we'll go to Matt Korn with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: So earlier this week, the White House announced a revision to these "Buy American" requirements. I was wondering how much, if any, potential incremental effect do you see from these changes. I asked because our understanding had been that many of these pu
componenttext: So earlier this week, the White House announced a revision to these "Buy American" requirements. I was wondering how much, if any, potential incremental effect do you see from these changes. I asked because our understanding had been that many of these public projects already had very high thresholds from melt and imported U.S. steel, but the administration appears to believe that there were loopholes that limited the effect in these of those rules. So I'm wondering what your view is.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, there were some loopholes in there. We're pleased to see those loopholes being closed. And you're right, a lot of new regulations already were in place, that it was "Buy American." And we wanted to make sure we did stress the point that this was "Bu
componenttext: Well, there were some loopholes in there. We're pleased to see those loopholes being closed. And you're right, a lot of new regulations already were in place, that it was "Buy American." And we wanted to make sure we did stress the point that this was "Buy American"-meant, melted, poured and rolled in the United States. So we made -- we took a little bit of the loophole away from that, that was existing. So in general, we'll see some impact. We do supply to the militaries, particularly out of our plate group and out of our SBQ group. So it's a positive impact to us, but it is not a major impact.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then to continue as we kind of go around the product groups here. There's been a lot of focus on hot-rolled coil, some focus on downstream. What's happening in the plate market in your view? Your volumes are off, the prices there are off, they
componenttext: Got it. And then to continue as we kind of go around the product groups here. There's been a lot of focus on hot-rolled coil, some focus on downstream. What's happening in the plate market in your view? Your volumes are off, the prices there are off, they've dropped to the 7 50 level. Is that 2-way function pronounced destocking? Or is there true demand challenges occurring for that particular product?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: There's 2 impacts that have occurred there on plate. First of all, you need to think about the weather conditions that we endured during the first half of this year, particularly in the first quarter, other plate products that went into bridges and so for
componenttext:
There's 2 impacts that have occurred there on plate. First of all, you need to think about the weather conditions that we endured during the first half of this year, particularly in the first quarter, other plate products that went into bridges and so forth, projects that you have to have good weather in order to be able to proceed. So there's a lot of projects out of that, that are on the books, but we haven't been able to move forward with them simply because of the extreme weather conditions. 
The other impact is, as you mentioned, aggressive destocking. Just as we said with the products earlier with tubular and with sheet products, the same occurred with plates. The inventory levels got way too high at the end of 2018 and we began the destocking program and at least a little bit of a time delay on that one simply because of -- the plate tends to trail hot band by about 2 months, 3 months, in terms of both volumes and pricing. So there was a little bit of a time delay, but basically, the same scenario played out in plate that we described earlier.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019

componenttext: And next, we'll go to Phil Gibbs with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: I was reading last night that one of your mill competitors in the North American sheet market, Arcelor, has formally asked its U.S. mills suppliers for concessions and price cuts. Question is are you either seeking pricing concessions from your mill suppl
componenttext: I was reading last night that one of your mill competitors in the North American sheet market, Arcelor, has formally asked its U.S. mills suppliers for concessions and price cuts. Question is are you either seeking pricing concessions from your mill suppliers or seeing any softness in inputs like electrodes and refractories, alloys or mill services?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, electrodes, we can talk about in a minute because that's a more specific issue, and we do see actually price going down in electrodes a little bit, about 7% this year over last year, but that's a very specific issue. There was a runup in electrodes
componenttext:
Well, electrodes, we can talk about in a minute because that's a more specific issue, and we do see actually price going down in electrodes a little bit, about 7% this year over last year, but that's a very specific issue. There was a runup in electrodes over the last couple of years that was unsustainable, and we're seeing it start to work its way down. But in general, I'll respond to your question. First of all, Nucor is a high-integrity company, we honor all the contracts that we have, and we will not go out and demand any price reductions on contracts that we have signed and the current numbers are in place. 
That said, if our suppliers do, in fact, offer our competitors better pricing, we will go and talk to them about that. We will not demand it. But what we mind then, that as the largest steel producer in the United States, we buy a whole lot more of everything than anyone else. And if they treat us any differently than our competition, we'll remember that when those contracts that we have come to an end and we go talk about who we're going to do business with in 2020. Does that answer your question?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Absolutely. And in terms of some of the stuff that was more -- the other things that were impacted by, I think, the China supply-side issues like refractories and alloys, what are you seeing there?
componenttext: Yes. Absolutely. And in terms of some of the stuff that was more -- the other things that were impacted by, I think, the China supply-side issues like refractories and alloys, what are you seeing there?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Refractories, they're still pretty high. We haven't seen much of a reduction in that. Alloys are still running pretty high, not quite up to the 2018 levels because just like everything else with steel, the less steel that we're producing, the less alloys
componenttext: Refractories, they're still pretty high. We haven't seen much of a reduction in that. Alloys are still running pretty high, not quite up to the 2018 levels because just like everything else with steel, the less steel that we're producing, the less alloys we need, the less refractory needs to be replaced. So the volumes go down and pricing comes down a little bit, that's more volume-related than anything else.

componenttext: Well, I'll speak to -- how about if I speak to the outlook for scrap over the entire third quarter because it's pretty tough to get definitive into 1 given month. But as we see the third quarter with scrap pricing, we see it up $20 to $30, somewhere in that neighborhood, and we don't think it's going to skyrocket out of control. But we do think, over the quarter, we'll be up $20 to $30. We think that the pig iron will probably be up somewhere in the neighborhood of $10 to $15. We're seeing some of that price reflected in the latest offers that we're getting. So $20 to $30 for scrap and somewhere maybe $10 to $15 on pig iron.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: It's hard to project when you -- right now, as we mentioned a couple of times, we are in a transition. We're in the cusp of a transition from a situation of severe to down destocking, to more normalized order entry rate from our service centers. Not being
componenttext:
It's hard to project when you -- right now, as we mentioned a couple of times, we are in a transition. We're in the cusp of a transition from a situation of severe to down destocking, to more normalized order entry rate from our service centers. Not being a service center ourselves, we don't know just exactly where those inventories are. Rather than say we know exactly what's going to happen with volumes going into the third quarter, I would say that we're going to transition. How quickly it ramps back up will determine how our third quarter volumes look relative to our second quarter. 
I think the important point to remember is this. We are seeing the transition and it's going back up. We see lead times expanding, and we see -- and a really important point here that allows me to sleep easily at night is that our end demand, our end demand is still very strong and user demand remains very strong. If we didn't see that through our OEM customers, I'd be a whole lot more worried about what the rest of the year was going to look like than I am right now.

Thank you, David. Well, I'll close by signing off by saying, again, I want to express our appreciation to our shareholders. We value your contribution and capital investment in our company, and we will treat it with great care. I want to say thank you to our customers. We're building our capabilities to better serve you, and we believe that together, we can build powerful partnerships with powerful results. Thanks for your interest in Nucor. Have a great day.
