componenttext: And next, we'll go to Timna Tanners with Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: So I wanted to ask about some of the capacity coming on in 2020 is replacing some of the domestic supply, specifically if you look at U.S. Steel's Fairfield mill and if you look at JSW's Baytown plate mill. Now I was just wondering if you have any thought
componenttext: So I wanted to ask about some of the capacity coming on in 2020 is replacing some of the domestic supply, specifically if you look at U.S. Steel's Fairfield mill and if you look at JSW's Baytown plate mill. Now I was just wondering if you have any thoughts about how that can affect the market and if Nucor is a supplier on any of those -- to any of those mills on raw materials or semi-finished products.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let's start with the semi-finished product since you asked that question about JSW coming online and U.S. Steel. We have been supplying both of those companies. But as a result of that, we built a pretty good product line of round billets and blooms
componenttext: Okay. Let's start with the semi-finished product since you asked that question about JSW coming online and U.S. Steel. We have been supplying both of those companies. But as a result of that, we built a pretty good product line of round billets and blooms that we can sell to the entire market. And we recognize that at least at this point in time, we're being told that we will lose that business in the next couple of years. We have been building a customer base outside of those 2, and we've been securing contracts with other customers. So we're confident that we'll be able to replace the tons from U.S. Steel and from JSW with other customers as they pull their business away from us.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. All right. So the second question I had was regarding the steel downstream business, so steel products. You succeeded in having improved profitability there as you had anticipated quarter-over-quarter, but when I look year-over-year,
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. All right. So the second question I had was regarding the steel downstream business, so steel products. You succeeded in having improved profitability there as you had anticipated quarter-over-quarter, but when I look year-over-year, it's still below last year's levels and I'm just confused as to how to think about that. I -- rule of thumb I had in mind was that when you have rising steel prices, generally, steel products lag. But in a declining steel price environment, one would think that margins can maybe be higher year-over-year. So just maybe if you could correct me if I'm wrong about that or how to think about what the right normal profitability is or how to think about what that trend can be going forward.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: When you look at the total downstream where -- I'm assuming you're including tube in that generalization, correct?
componenttext: When you look at the total downstream where -- I'm assuming you're including tube in that generalization, correct?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm just looking at EBIT per ton of the segment.
componenttext: Yes. I'm just looking at EBIT per ton of the segment.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Tubing is in that segment.
componenttext: Yes. Tubing is in that segment.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So when you look at tube, that's really been what's pulling down the downstream business. The tubular business right now -- our tubular business right now is suffering from some of the same things that we see on the steel side, bloated inventories in
componenttext: Yes. So when you look at tube, that's really been what's pulling down the downstream business. The tubular business right now -- our tubular business right now is suffering from some of the same things that we see on the steel side, bloated inventories in the service centers that resulted in lower orders that, of course, drives the price down, that, of course, drives the margins down. So this is a -- in our opinion, this is the result of too high of an inventory build during last year and the aggressive destocking that you see, not only in our steel products, but also in tubes. So that's probably the biggest impact on our downstream business not doing as well as we anticipated and not doing as well as we did last year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: So potential for that to still normalize at -- once inventory levels normalize in those end markets, is that what we should think about, or any way to think conceptually about what that looks like normally?
componenttext: So potential for that to still normalize at -- once inventory levels normalize in those end markets, is that what we should think about, or any way to think conceptually about what that looks like normally?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that this is a question of what's really driving the buying reductions in tubular and in our steel. Now overall, we believe that the issue is too much inventory in the system that has to work its way through and at the time that it goes throu
componenttext: Yes. I think that this is a question of what's really driving the buying reductions in tubular and in our steel. Now overall, we believe that the issue is too much inventory in the system that has to work its way through and at the time that it goes through. You have to remember, when you talk about tubular, 80% of the tubulars are sold through service centers. So this really impacts -- this issue of inventory really impacts the tubular business. But it's also true of our steel business, as we talked about many times in the past. The inventories do not necessarily -- service center shipments do not necessarily indicate what's happening with true end-use demand. We believe that end-use demand is still very strong. We see that in our order entry rate for OEMs versus our order entry rate for service centers. When you look at our order entry rate for OEMs, we're actually up in the first half by about 4% compared to the 3-year average. Whereas if you look at order entry for service centers, we're down 14% compared to the 3-year average. So that's a pretty good indicator to us that end demand is still pretty strong. Of course, we talk to our customers who are basically telling us the same thing, and I'm speaking in general now both of steel and our tubular products also.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: And next, we'll go to Chris Terry with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And next, we'll go to Chris Terry with Deutsche Bank.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: John and Jim, a couple of questions from me. Just in terms of the volume, you mentioned that second half volumes will be more in line with real demand. Have you seen any marked pickup, I guess, in July in the service center buying? And how do we think abo
componenttext: John and Jim, a couple of questions from me. Just in terms of the volume, you mentioned that second half volumes will be more in line with real demand. Have you seen any marked pickup, I guess, in July in the service center buying? And how do we think about maybe second half on first half of this year and maybe second half on second half of last year?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'll start with the -- with just general comments, and Jim, you can comment on the year-over-year performance and half-over-half performance. I mentioned earlier that after the first $40-a-ton increase in sheet pricing, we did see a pickup in orders for o
componenttext: I'll start with the -- with just general comments, and Jim, you can comment on the year-over-year performance and half-over-half performance. I mentioned earlier that after the first $40-a-ton increase in sheet pricing, we did see a pickup in orders for our sheet products, and that came from both our OEM customers, but also from our service centers. When we meet with our service centers, we talk about what they think is going to happen in the second half. They feel that the demand, the end demand for their products will be steady. It's still strong. They talk about the need for making sure that they get their inventories completely down, which is what they are striving to accomplish. But one of the things that we're seeing also, that should be a good indicator of moving in -- and it's early in the game so I don't want to be too overconfident here, but we are cautiously optimistic that we've hit the bottom on pricing and on volumes. We see our lead times are beginning to stretch out a little bit. Whenever that starts to happen, that encourages the service centers to come back into the market. Now with the OEMs, it's more of a steady-state situation. So after the $40-a-ton increase, we believe that, that represented the bottom of the market. Service centers, whenever you see pricing start to go up, they come back into the market. So we think that, that bodes well for the second half of the year, and we'll see how it plays out.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: And relative to your question about the second half of this year versus last year, obviously, we don't give guidance for the half year. We're saying third quarter is going to be down just because of where margins are at, having bottomed recently, and what
componenttext: And relative to your question about the second half of this year versus last year, obviously, we don't give guidance for the half year. We're saying third quarter is going to be down just because of where margins are at, having bottomed recently, and what we see going forward. But from a volume perspective, we certainly saw destocking begin in the second half of last year and then carry into 2019. And there will always be a seasonal slowdown in the fourth quarter, but we would be -- we would expect right now, and this is a long-shot guess, that volumes in the fourth quarter of this year should be better than last year because we don't expect to see the destocking component in the fourth quarter, we'll just see the normal seasonal slowdown that we'd expect.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: I think if I can just build on that for a minute because I think it's important to think about what took place in 2018 as it related to the 232 and everything that was going on. First of all, if you go all the way back to 2017, with tax reform and deregul
componenttext:
I think if I can just build on that for a minute because I think it's important to think about what took place in 2018 as it related to the 232 and everything that was going on. First of all, if you go all the way back to 2017, with tax reform and deregulation, that was really a shot in the arm for manufacturing. And frankly, the order entry rate picked up, demand for steel picked up, and it was growing all through 2017. Towards the end of '17, but particularly in the beginning of '18, a lot of our customers were reading about the fact that when the tariffs came into effect, we would not -- they would not be able to get the steel that they needed to fill their customers' orders. That created somewhat of a panic, both with the OEM and with our service center customers. They were convinced that the domestic capacity would not be enough to supply all the needs that they had to keep their customers happy. 
But as it played out, 232 came into effect, the imports did go down, and domestic capacity was enabled, was, in fact, able to start up again and fill the need. But during that time when they were afraid of getting -- not being able to get the steel, they built their inventories to very high levels. And of course, domestic capacity came on, everything settled down, the order rate and pricing returned to more normalized levels, but they've maintained this high inventory. At the end of the year, they wanted to get rid of that overblown inventory and they began to aggressively destock. So what happens then, okay, they destock volume. All the volumes coming into the mills go down. Pricing results, as a result, goes down. And the next thing you know, we get into this spiral of -- in fact, the aggressive destocking was so intense that towards the end of last year and into the first half of this year, we had service centers selling to other service centers. So it became a very difficult situation. And as always happens in our business, we overshoot things. Now we think that we're getting to the point where the inventories are down to more normal levels, and we expect to see more normalized ordering rates in the next quarter.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just one quick follow-up. In terms of the end markets, you talked about the 2/3 that you're cautiously optimistic around. The other 1/3, I assume that -- is that related to autos, or what is that market or which markets are those specifically that you're
componenttext: Just one quick follow-up. In terms of the end markets, you talked about the 2/3 that you're cautiously optimistic around. The other 1/3, I assume that -- is that related to autos, or what is that market or which markets are those specifically that you're still working out?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: We think that automotive is going to be down about 2%, so that's one of the markets that we would say is weakening as we go into the second half of 2019. That said, our market share within automotive continues to grow. So there'll be a small pie, and we'l
componenttext:
We think that automotive is going to be down about 2%, so that's one of the markets that we would say is weakening as we go into the second half of 2019. That said, our market share within automotive continues to grow. So there'll be a small pie, and we'll have a larger piece of that small pie. So the impact will be less felt by Nucor than others in our space. 
Another one that I remember being -- looking from the chart that was down would be power transmission. There was a whole bunch of power transmission projects that were wrapped up at the end of 2018. So power transmission is an industry that we expect to be down also. Agriculture will be down a little bit as we see it going forward into the second half of this year also.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019

componenttext: And next, we'll go to Matt Korn with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: So earlier this week, the White House announced a revision to these "Buy American" requirements. I was wondering how much, if any, potential incremental effect do you see from these changes. I ask because our understanding had been that many of these publ
componenttext: So earlier this week, the White House announced a revision to these "Buy American" requirements. I was wondering how much, if any, potential incremental effect do you see from these changes. I ask because our understanding had been that many of these public projects already had very high thresholds for melted and poured U.S. steel, but the administration appears to believe that there were loopholes that limited the effectiveness of those rules. So I'm wondering what your view is.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, there were some loopholes in there. We're pleased to see those loopholes being closed. And you're right, a lot of new regulations already were in place, that it was "Buy American." And we wanted to make sure we did stress the point that this was [ w
componenttext: Well, there were some loopholes in there. We're pleased to see those loopholes being closed. And you're right, a lot of new regulations already were in place, that it was "Buy American." And we wanted to make sure we did stress the point that this was [ what ] "Buy American" meant: melted, poured and rolled in the United States. So we made -- we took a little bit of the loophole away from that, that was existing. So in general, we'll see some impact. We do supply to the militaries, particularly out of our plate group and out of our SBQ group. So it's a positive impact to us, but it is not a major impact.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then to continue as we kind of go around the product groups here. There's been a lot of focus on hot-rolled coil, some focus on downstream. What's happening in the plate market, in your view? Your volumes are off, the prices there are off, the
componenttext: Got it. And then to continue as we kind of go around the product groups here. There's been a lot of focus on hot-rolled coil, some focus on downstream. What's happening in the plate market, in your view? Your volumes are off, the prices there are off, they've dropped to the 7 50 level. Is that 2-way function pronounced destocking? Or is there true demand challenges occurring for that particular product?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: There's 2 impacts that have occurred there on plate. First of all, you need to think about the weather conditions that we endured during the first half of this year, particularly in the first quarter, a lot of plate products that went into bridges and so
componenttext:
There's 2 impacts that have occurred there on plate. First of all, you need to think about the weather conditions that we endured during the first half of this year, particularly in the first quarter, a lot of plate products that went into bridges and so forth, projects that you have to have good weather in order to be able to proceed. So there's a lot of projects that are on the books, but we haven't been able to move forward with them simply because of the extreme weather conditions. 
The other impact is, as you mentioned, aggressive destocking. Just as we said with the products earlier with tubular and with sheet products, the same occurred with plates. The inventory levels got way too high at the end of 2018 and we began the destocking program. And a little bit of a time delay on that one simply because of -- the plate tends to trail hot band by about 2 months, 3 months, in terms of both volumes and pricing. So there was a little bit of a time delay, but basically, the same scenario played out in plate that we described earlier.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019

componenttext: And next, we'll go to Phil Gibbs with KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: I was reading last night that one of your mill competitors in the North American sheet market, Arcelor, has formally asked its U.S. mill suppliers for concessions and price cuts. Question is are you either seeking pricing concessions from your mill suppli
componenttext: I was reading last night that one of your mill competitors in the North American sheet market, Arcelor, has formally asked its U.S. mill suppliers for concessions and price cuts. Question is are you either seeking pricing concessions from your mill suppliers or seeing any softness in inputs like electrodes and refractories, alloys or mill services?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, electrodes, we can talk about in a minute because that's a more specific issue, and we do see actually price going down in electrodes a little bit, about 7% this year over last year, but that's a very specific issue. There was a run-up in electrodes
componenttext:
Well, electrodes, we can talk about in a minute because that's a more specific issue, and we do see actually price going down in electrodes a little bit, about 7% this year over last year, but that's a very specific issue. There was a run-up in electrodes over the last couple of years that was unsustainable, and we're seeing it start to work its way down. But in general, I'll respond to your question. First of all, Nucor is a high-integrity company, we honor all the contracts that we have, and we will not go out and demand any price reductions on contracts that we have signed, and the current numbers are in place. 
That said, if our suppliers do, in fact, offer our competitors better pricing, we will go and talk to them about that. We will not demand it, but we'll remind them that as the largest steel producer in the United States, we buy a whole lot more of everything than anyone else. And if they treat us any differently than our competition, we'll remember that when those contracts that we have come to an end and we go talk about who we're going to do business with in 2020. Does that answer your question?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Absolutely. And in terms of some of the stuff that was more -- the other things that were impacted by, I think, the China supply-side issues like refractories and alloys, what are you seeing there?
componenttext: Yes. Absolutely. And in terms of some of the stuff that was more -- the other things that were impacted by, I think, the China supply-side issues like refractories and alloys, what are you seeing there?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Refractories, they're still pretty high. We haven't seen much of a reduction in that. Alloys are still running pretty high, not quite up to the 2018 levels because just like everything else with steel, the less steel that we're producing, the less alloys
componenttext: Refractories, they're still pretty high. We haven't seen much of a reduction in that. Alloys are still running pretty high, not quite up to the 2018 levels because just like everything else with steel, the less steel that we're producing, the less alloys we need, the less refractory needs to be replaced. So the volumes go down and pricing comes down a little bit, but that's more volume-related than anything else.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll speak to -- how about if I speak to the outlook for scrap over the entire third quarter, because it's pretty tough to get definitive into 1 given month. But as we see the third quarter with scrap pricing, we see it up $20 to $30, somewhere in t
componenttext: Well, I'll speak to -- how about if I speak to the outlook for scrap over the entire third quarter, because it's pretty tough to get definitive into 1 given month. But as we see the third quarter with scrap pricing, we see it up $20 to $30, somewhere in that neighborhood, and we don't think it's going to skyrocket out of control. But we do think, over the quarter, we'll be up $20 to $30. We think that the pig iron will probably be up somewhere in the neighborhood of $10 to $15. We're seeing some of that price reflected in the latest offers that we're getting. So $20 to $30 for scrap and somewhere maybe $10 to $15 on pig iron.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 18, 2019
componenttextpreview: It's hard to project when you -- right now, as we mentioned a couple of times, we are in a transition. We're in the cusp of a transition from a situation of severe down -- destocking, to a more normalized order entry rate from our service centers. Not bei
componenttext:
It's hard to project when you -- right now, as we mentioned a couple of times, we are in a transition. We're in the cusp of a transition from a situation of severe down -- destocking, to a more normalized order entry rate from our service centers. Not being a service center ourselves, we don't know just exactly where those inventories are. Rather than say we know exactly what's going to happen with volumes going into the third quarter, I would say that we're going to transition. How quickly it ramps back up will determine how our third quarter volumes look relative to our second quarter. 
I think the important point to remember is this: We are seeing the transition and it's going back up. We see lead times expanding, and we see -- and a really important point here that allows me to sleep easily at night is that our end demand, our end demand is still very strong and user demand remains very strong. If we didn't see that through our OEM customers, I'd be a whole lot more worried about what the rest of the year was going to look like than I am right now.

We're building our capabilities to better serve you, and we believe that together, we can build powerful partnerships with powerful results. And finally, to my Nucor teammates, thank you for what you're doing for Nucor every day. And most importantly, thank you for doing it safely.
Thanks for your interest in Nucor. Have a great day.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation Third Quarter of 2019 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] Certain statements made during the conference call will be forward-looking statements th
componenttext:
Good day, everyone, and welcome to the Nucor Corporation Third Quarter of 2019 Earnings Call. As a reminder, today's call is being recorded. [Operator Instructions] 
Certain statements made during the conference call will be forward-looking statements that involve risks and uncertainties. The words we expect, believe, anticipate and variations of such words and similar expressions are intended to identify those forward-looking statements, which are based on management's current expectations and information that is currently available. Although Nucor believes they are based on reasonable assumptions, there can be no assurance that future events will not affect their accuracy. More information about the risks and uncertainties relating to these forward-looking statements may be found in Nucor's latest 10-K and subsequently filed 10-Qs, which are available on the SEC's and Nucor's website. 
The forward-looking statements made in this conference call speak only as of this date, and Nucor does not assume any obligation to update them, as either -- either as a result of new information, future events or otherwise.
For opening remarks and introductions, I would like to turn the call over to Mr. John Ferriola, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer of Nucor Corporation. Please go ahead, sir.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our third quarter earnings call and for your interest in Nucor. Other members of Nucor's executive team are also on the call today, including Leon Topalian, our President and Chief Operating Officer; Jim Frias,
componenttext:
Good afternoon. Thank you for joining us for our third quarter earnings call and for your interest in Nucor. Other members of Nucor's executive team are also on the call today, including Leon Topalian, our President and Chief Operating Officer; Jim Frias, our Chief Financial Officer; Craig Feldman, responsible for Raw Materials; Ladd Hall, responsible for sheet products; Ray Napolitan, responsible for Engineered Bar Products; Mary Emily Slate, responsible for plate, structural and tubular products; Dave Sumoski, responsible for Merchant Bar and Rebar Products; and Chad Utermark, responsible for Fabricated Construction Products.
Last month, I announced my retirement from Nucor effective at the end of this year. One of my priorities during my time as CEO has been to make certain that we have a deep bench of leadership talent and a robust management succession plan in place. I know we have succeeded on both fronts. Identifying the right leaders is a key component of our company's future success. 
I am delighted that the Nucor Board of Directors has elected Leon Topalian to succeed me as Nucor's next CEO. Leon has proven himself to be an exceptional leader throughout his 23-year career at Nucor.
Since 2017, he has served as Executive Vice President responsible for Nucor's plate and structural steel mills. Prior to joining our corporate senior leadership, Leon was General Manager at 2 facilities: at our Nucor Yamato structural steel mill and our Kankakee Illinois Bar Mill. With the support of our leadership team and all of our teammates, I am confident that Leon will guide Nucor towards continued success. 
I'm also confident that we have an executive leadership team that is second to none in our industry and I know Leon and the Board feel the same way.
Before I provide comments on our third quarter results, I want to say a few words about safety. One of my proudest accomplishments during my time as CEO is the way that our entire organization has improved our safety performance. I want to thank all of my teammates who have constant focus on working safely. We are having one of our best years ever for safety performance. Let's keep that focus as we move closer to our goal which will always be: Zero incidents at every Nucor facility. Any injury is one too many.
Now on to our third quarter results. We saw continued strong performance from our metal buildings, piling, joist and deck divisions as well as improved performance in our rebar fabrication divisions. The performance reflects excellent execution by our teammates and continued stable conditions in the nonresidential construction market. 
Overall spending in the nonresidential construction market, which typically accounts for approximately 1/2 of our company's shipments remain at healthy levels. 
After a brief summer rally, plate and sheet market conditions soften in the third quarter. Excess inventory throughout the supply chain has resulted in continued destocking by our customers. Service center industry data indicates that inventories remain low. 
In addition, our OEM customers have become cautious about buying as we head into the year-end. However, we do believe that both our service center and OEM customers will start restocking to meet demand as 2020 gets underway. 
Looking out further into next year, the pending 2020 elections and current trade issues, such as the unresolved status of the USMCA agreement for North America, are creating some more uncertainty in the market. And while it's difficult to predict steel markets that far into the future, we continue to have great confidence in Nucor's business fundamentals and our long-term strategy. 
Finally, let me remind you all that we have several more of our growth projects starting up in the fourth quarter that will give us the capability to produce more of the products that our customers are asking us to make. We have said many times: these investments position us for continued success by taking advantage of specific market opportunity. We expect they will further enhance Nucor's position as a steel market leader. 
I'm now going to turn the call over to Leon to provide comments and an update on several of our growth initiatives. Leon?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. I'd like to begin by saying how honored I am to have the opportunity to lead this amazing company. I look forward to continuing the proud traditions that have made Nucor the premier steel and steel products company for the last 50 years. A h
componenttext:
Thanks, John. I'd like to begin by saying how honored I am to have the opportunity to lead this amazing company. I look forward to continuing the proud traditions that have made Nucor the premier steel and steel products company for the last 50 years. A hallmark of our success has and will continue to be our culture, which begins with the nearly 27,000 team members who make up the Nucor family. 
Our culture drew me to this company 23 years ago and it inspires me daily. And the most important value in our culture is safety, taking care of our team is the most important responsibility we have. I take it very personally and will work tirelessly to continue Nucor's quest of becoming the safest steel company in the world.
Since the announcement, I've been visiting many of our divisions and have been humbled by the warm reception I received. In talking with our team, it's obvious they are deeply engaged in our mission and just as excited about Nucor's future as I am. That excitement is especially evident among our team members who are bringing new growth online. Let me just say thank you for your hard work, dedication, commitment and never losing sight of our most important value, safety.
I'd like now to provide you with an update on some of the projects we're bringing online. At Nucor Steel Arkansas, our Hickman team continues to increase production and improve yield performance in our new specialty. The mill's flexibility is a key feature with its dual configuration, Hickman's new cold mill can change from a high reduction mill for the advanced strength steels in the future to a very efficient for high mill in just 6 minutes. This flexibility separates us from our competition and allows us to efficiently offer a broader range of value-added products. There is no other carbon mill like this in North America. 
Nucor Steel Gallatin's new galvanizing iron team coded their first coils on September 27. With 500,000 tons of annual capacity, Gallatin 72-inch galvanizing line is the widest hot-rolled galvanizing facility in North America.
Gallatin is extremely well positioned to grow Nucor's share of the underserved Midwest heavy gauge galvanizing hotbed market. 
At our Ohio rebar mill, commissioning of the new in-line rolling mill was completed in August and the Marion team is currently ramping up production. Early next year, Marrion will also install quench and temper equipment to reduce alloy costs. 
These investments combined with a more energy-efficient reheat furnace installed last year will position Marion as the low cost producer in the region. Other projects on track for start-up by the end of the year include: Nucor Steel Kankakee MBQ rolling mill, our new rebar micro mill in Sedalia, Missouri and the galvanizing line we're building in Mexico with JFE steel. 
As we have said before, we are not adding capacity simply to get bigger. These projects target the fine market opportunities where we are confident that we will compete and win highly profitable market share. 
We are also responding to feedback from our customers regarding their product needs particularly for value-added products. Nucor is doing more than adding capacity. Nucor is increasing our capabilities to provide our customers with superior value.
we achieved that with unique product properties, matched product breath, industry-leading on-time delivery and unrivaled quality. Every growth project we are implementing builds on our competitive strengths to serve new product and geographic markets. We these investments, we are increasing Nucor's long-term earnings power. This is the same strategy Nucor has successfully executed through numerous market cycles over the past 5 decades. 
At this time, I will turn the call over to Jim Frias for a review of our financial results. Jim?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Leon. Nucor reported third quarter of 2019 earnings of $0.90 per diluted share. These results exceeded our guidance range of $0.75 to $0.80 due to better-than-expected performance at our sheet and bar steel mills as well as from several steel prod
componenttext:
Thanks, Leon. Nucor reported third quarter of 2019 earnings of $0.90 per diluted share. These results exceeded our guidance range of $0.75 to $0.80 due to better-than-expected performance at our sheet and bar steel mills as well as from several steel products businesses, most notably joist, deck and building systems.
It's worth noting that both our joist and deck business and our metal buildings business are on pace for record year in 2019. Both of these business groups are benefiting from lower steel prices and excellent commercial execution. The metal buildings business is also benefiting from a restructuring that has realigned capacity and reduced fixed costs. 
Earnings from our steel mill segment were lower than the second quarter due to declining metal margins. Sheet and plate products experienced the greatest pricing pressure as custom destocking continued in the third quarter. Total steel mill shipments in the third quarter were comparable to the second quarter. 
Steel mill shipments to internal customers represented 21% of total steel mill shipments in the third quarter, an increase from 19% in the second quarter. Nucor's downstream channels to market strategy remains a key competitive strength of our company.
Earnings from our steel products segment improved compared to the second quarter of this year and to the year ago third quarter. Nonresidential construction market conditions remained positive. Our businesses appear to have benefited from both recovery from weather-related disruptions earlier in the year and seasonally stronger construction months. 
Results from our raw materials segment decreased compared to the second quarter due to further margin compression at our direct reduced iron or DRI operations. In addition, our Louisiana DRI facility began its planned outage in early September and that is expected to continue until mid-November. 
Our third quarter results included roughly $28 million of preoperating and start-up costs related to strategic investment projects compared with approximately $21 million in the second quarter of 2019 and approximately $11 million in the year ago quarter.
First 9 months of 2019 cash provided from operations was approximately $2.1 billion, up from about $1.9 billion for the year ago period. Nucor continues to benefit from its highly variable cost structure. Accounts receivable, payables and inventory were a source of approximately $500 million during the first 9 months of 2019, reflecting consistent working capital management in a declining steel pricing environment. 
Capital expenditures totaled $985 million through the first 9 months of 2019. Our full year 2019 capital spending budget is now approximately $1.5 billion, a decrease from our prior forecast of $1.8 billion. This change reflects the timing of expected outlays over the balance of this year. 
Cash return to shareholders during the first 9 months of 2019 totaled $567 million. We paid dividends of $369 million and stock repurchases totaled $198 million.
Thus far in 2019, we have returned 49% of our net income to our shareholders while also investing for long-term profitable growth. Nucor's financial condition remains strong. We ended the quarter with $1.9 billion in cash and short-term investment. 
With total debt outstanding of approximately $4.3 billion, our gross debt-to-capital ratio was 28% at the end of the third quarter. Our $1.5 billion unsecured revolving credit facility remains undrawn and does not mature until April of 2023.
Our next material debt maturity is in 2022 for approximately $600 million. Now turning to the outlook. Nucor's earnings in the fourth quarter of 2019 are expected to be lower than the third quarter. While nonresidential construction markets remain broadly stable and healthy, manufacturing sector activity has slowed down. 
We expect earnings in the steel mills segment to further decrease from the third quarter due to an impact of lower steel prices at the end of the third quarter, which will be realized in fourth quarter shipments. We believe steel prices have bottomed. 
The profitability of the steel products segment is expected to decrease slightly due to normal year-end seasonality. The performance of our raw material segment is expected to decline in the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter due to the impact of our Louisiana DRI plants, outage continuing until mid-November as well as further margin pressure throughout our raw materials businesses. 
Thank you for your interest in our company. I will now turn the call over back to John.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jim. Before we take your questions, let me make a few other comments. I recently had the privilege of joining Nucor Steel Indiana team to celebrate 30 years of making steel in Crawfordsville. Three decades ago, our team revolutionized the Americ
componenttext:
Thanks, Jim. Before we take your questions, let me make a few other comments. I recently had the privilege of joining Nucor Steel Indiana team to celebrate 30 years of making steel in Crawfordsville. 
Three decades ago, our team revolutionized the American steel industry, becoming the first thin slab operation to produce sheet steel using an electrical furnace. 600 people joined us for the celebration, including local officials, teammates, customers, suppliers and friends and family. 
Congratulations again to the Crawfordsville team for all they have accomplished over the past 30 years. With regard to trade policy, imports continued to supply a shrinking share of the U.S. demand, thanks to the cost competitiveness of our market-oriented domestic steel industry and effective trade enforcement. 
At Nucor, we will not take this progress for granted and we will continue to press for sensible legislation, regulation and enforcement. We also remain hopeful that Congress will approve the USMCA this year. We see it as a meaningful modernization of NAFTA that will benefit the U.S. economy and the domestic manufacturing sector in particular. 
We would now be happy to take your questions. Operator?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019

componenttext: Downstream steel products results were fairly strong this quarter. Just want to see if you can provide an update on the efficiency initiatives if there's more to expect there as well as the rebar fabrication business. Was it profitable? And also, how those backlogs look compared to a year ago and how you see the nonresi construction moving forward?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Let me start with some comments on the business model changes that we've made in our building systems can in our full credit operations. I'm really proud of the job that the team has done. And we've always said that we have great teammates in those operat
componenttext: Let me start with some comments on the business model changes that we've made in our building systems can in our full credit operations. I'm really proud of the job that the team has done. And we've always said that we have great teammates in those operations, and we're working in a model that needed to be adjusted. We've made the adjustments. And we're seeing very positive results. Is there more to go? We always wanted to get better. We always said that we can do better to more than we are doing today. And I'm confident that as we gain more experience with the new models that we will continue to see improvements in those operations. Chad, do you want to add anything to that?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, John. Just a couple of comments. So our joist and deck metal buildings and rebar fabrication backlogs are slightly improved the EOU. These end-use markets are led by warehouse, manufacturing and commercial projects. And we see them sustainabl
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, John. Just a couple of comments. So our joist and deck metal buildings and rebar fabrication backlogs are slightly improved the EOU. These end-use markets are led by warehouse, manufacturing and commercial projects. And we see them sustainable into the first quarter of 2020. So overall, yes, we're very excited about the performance of our downstream product groups and look forward as we head into 2020.

This question was about profitability rebar fab. We did make money in the rebar, for sure.
May be just to wrap it up. I'd like to say thank you to our teammates in all of those operations, making changes like this, these are not easy to do. And the support that we've got from our teammates in all those operations is what resulted in the success that we've seen as we've made these businesses decisions. So thank you all for the hard work, thank you for your willingness to adjust to a changing marketplace and more to come.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: So speaking in general terms across all our products without getting into specifics. We do feel that in many of our products, the pricing has bottomed. Things that drive that are couple things: Number one, you're right. We see the scrap market starting to
componenttext:
So speaking in general terms across all our products without getting into specifics. We do feel that in many of our products, the pricing has bottomed. Things that drive that are couple things: Number one, you're right. We see the scrap market starting to improve. We anticipate that the scrap pricing will go up about $20. May be next month, $20, $25, somewhere in that neighborhood. We think that trend will continue throughout the year. Our best guess on scrap pricing right now for the year is up $20 to $40 by the end of the year. 
The other thing that I would say that's driving our belief is that when we start to look at our bookings, particularly in our sheet area, over the last several weeks, bookings have improved. We see more energy and particularly in the hotbend. Coal oil and has always been fairly strong. We haven't seen much of a decline in those 2 products. Hot band, as you know, was really challenged for the first part of this year. We talk about this in the past. Overstocking of inventories last year. The tough weather conditions at the beginning of this year. Destocking this year. These are all things that have contributed to challenging steel market during this year. We see that ending. When we look at MSCI inventories, we see them at -- I mean, they are incredibly low levels and lower we seen in many, many years. And compared to last year, they are down and at this time -- t same's time last year, they are down fairly significantly. So these are all things that we see driving our comments that we think that the pricing as well as the will increase as we go forward. One more point that I will make is -- first, Leon, you want to say something?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. As well Martin, the MSCI numbers, as John pointed out, are down roughly 14% to 20% year-over-year. And so if you look at that compared to the peak, which occurred in the 2015 to 2016 range, it's almost -- over 20% down compared to that point. So aga
componenttext: Sure. As well Martin, the MSCI numbers, as John pointed out, are down roughly 14% to 20% year-over-year. And so if you look at that compared to the peak, which occurred in the 2015 to 2016 range, it's almost -- over 20% down compared to that point. So again, year-over-year, we're approximately 14% to 20% across all of our points. Additionally, as we ended the first quarter, particularly in sheet, we anticipated that being and usually is a much stronger quarter as we begin the year and we look forward to that as we enter the next quarter.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019

componenttext: So we see as we see the turn over the New Year, we see business getting over across all of our products. As we said, I think Chad pointed out, we had a record many of our downstream businesses. We anticipate another strong year going into -- with our downstream business next year. We see improving conditions going into the new year in our steel products.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'll start with structural and maybe will turn it over to [indiscernible] to make some comments on tubular. Structural business has been challenged this year. No doubt about it. A lot of it was a result of heavy stocking last year particularly in the last
componenttext:
I'll start with structural and maybe will turn it over to [indiscernible] to make some comments on tubular. Structural business has been challenged this year. No doubt about it. A lot of it was a result of heavy stocking last year particularly in the last half of last year. We saw service centers stocking up pretty heavily. And of course, beginning of this year, as I mentioned earlier, weather conditions prohibited a lot of the construction from consuming some of that over stocking and we've been going through a destocking period now. I would comment that we think that we've seen the bottom of that stocking, destocking now. It's coming to an end and we expect that to pick up a little bit. 
We also expect to see some benefit from the recent determinations by commerce on fabricated structural steel. We had some very positive preliminary determinations. We're looking forward to some final also positive determination early part of next year. So those are some of the things that are driving where we were and why we feel things are going to get better. Mary, you want to comment on tubular?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Absolutely. On tubular products, the OEM and the fabricator activity has not been bad this year. It's been pretty stable, but we've also experienced some destocking and people bringing their inventory to lower levels. We feel that, that product group thou
componenttext: Absolutely. On tubular products, the OEM and the fabricator activity has not been bad this year. It's been pretty stable, but we've also experienced some destocking and people bringing their inventory to lower levels. We feel that, that product group though has seen the lowest levels of inventory and will start more normal buying patterns here in the fourth quarter. So we expect things to get a little bit better. There's also some really good project activity out there that we've been very successful in getting. So we look to a bright future.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: John, one other point I'd add and Hunter, you asked about the trends in being one of the things that I would share with you is being a market leader in beams, we've -- it's been one of our most profitable groups. And as you've seen and we've reported, whi
componenttext: John, one other point I'd add and Hunter, you asked about the trends in being one of the things that I would share with you is being a market leader in beams, we've -- it's been one of our most profitable groups. And as you've seen and we've reported, while the utilization the nature of that 65 to 70 range, because of our market leadership position, we were able to maintain a very profitable position in this market and serve our customers' needs. We'll continuing to expand or our products in our offerings like the great 65 [indiscernible] to our construction customers and supply the needs that they're asking us for.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019

componenttext: Team, couple of questions from my side. All the best, John, in retirement. Just firstly on your capital for the quarter. Noticed you didn't do anything on the buybacks. So I just wondered if you could provide a little bit more color on that. I appreciate you got a 40% minimum payout ratio and you've already met that. I think you commented at 49%. But just a little bit surprised when you've back a little bit on the capital timing that there was no buyback in the quarter.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks for that question. We've got a very intentional process for how we think about returning capital to investors as well as investing in our business or capital allocation. Mindset begins with idea that we want to invest strategic long-term growt
componenttext:
Yes. Thanks for that question. We've got a very intentional process for how we think about returning capital to investors as well as investing in our business or capital allocation. Mindset begins with idea that we want to invest strategic long-term growth and of course, we do have a number of projects in our pipeline. And as you kind of noted, we're a little behind in terms of the spending on some of those capital projects. So that resulted in us temporarily having more cash in the balance sheet. That's going to catch up pretty quickly over the next 6 to 9 months and we're going to need some of that cash to fund a lot of the capital project that are in process. 
But aside from that, as to think about we've been dealing with this idea that we want to return a minimum of 40% of our earnings. And then we also want to maintain a debt-to-capital ratio that supports our strong investment grade credit rating. And at times when that debt-to-capital ratio becomes too low, we will return more like we did late last year when we have a view that we have depth of liquidity. 
And so it's possible we'll do more before the end of the year, but it depends on our forecast of cash going into 2020. Because working capital has benefited us to the tune of roughly $0.5 billion million this year. If steel prices reverse and scrap price is reversed, we're going to need -- we're going to have some need of cash in working capital next year. We definitely will see acceleration of capital spending. So we're being thoughtful about not just where we stand with cash today but where we expect cash to be through next year.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just in terms of corporate illuminations. It's quite a bit lower than what we expected for the quarter. Appreciate that the steel mills profitability obviously has an impact on what that number would be. Can just talk a little bit about some of
componenttext: Okay. And just in terms of corporate illuminations. It's quite a bit lower than what we expected for the quarter. Appreciate that the steel mills profitability obviously has an impact on what that number would be. Can just talk a little bit about some of the one-offs in that and the difficulty in the forecasting of that number?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. I'm going to answer 2 questions that you're not asking but is sort of related. As she and -- marketing has also been dramatically lower. So the piece that's reflected in both places is incentive compensation. Incentive compensation in the quarter is
componenttext:
Yes. I'm going to answer 2 questions that you're not asking but is sort of related. As she and -- marketing has also been dramatically lower. So the piece that's reflected in both places is incentive compensation. Incentive compensation in the quarter is about $88 million less this year than last year year-to-date. It's about $104 million less and that's affecting both the [indiscernible] line and the marketing admin and underline. 
So that's just because we're making less money and profiteering, the biggest piece of that profit sharing is employees below the level of Vice President. And then additionally, we have the profit eliminate this year. In the third quarter, it was a benefit of about $34 million. Last year, it was an expense of about $67 million. So as margin and steel fall, we revalue that inventory. We sometimes get a benefit from their company eliminations. To get a benefit to the third quarter this year year-to-date they are benefit is about $91 million and last year, the expense was about $228 million. So that's been a pretty serious swing as well. Those are the 2 biggest factors affecting the change in Elam's and incentive comp is the biggest factor affecting SG&A.

componenttext: And the last one for me just in terms of the end market. You spoken about most of them but I just wondered if you could comment on the orders sector specifically. Maybe just I think you normally give color on your 24 end markets maybe just where they're tracking.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll start with a second question first. And just as a general statement, we feel that about 2/3 of the markets that we serve are either stable or growing, somewhere around 60% to 65% of them and that feels about right for us given the conditions ou
componenttext:
Well, I'll start with a second question first. And just as a general statement, we feel that about 2/3 of the markets that we serve are either stable or growing, somewhere around 60% to 65% of them and that feels about right for us given the conditions out there in the economy. 
Your question about automotive. Now certainly, the automotive market has edge down and forecasting somewhere around 16.8, 16.9. And moment just the other day almost 17. So it's down a little bit from last year for certain but still 16 8 to 16 9, those are pretty good numbers. And the important -- I think important thing to note for us is that we continue to take a bigger share of that smaller pie. If you look at the tonnage that we sent into the automotive business this year compared to last year, we were up's about 15% tons into automotive this year as compared to last year. So we continue to grow our market share and although the pie use shrinking, we continue to get a big piece of that smaller pie. We feel really good about where we are in automotive. We are confident that we will continue to grow when we look at next year, we are protecting 2020 and 2021 even more tonnage going into those markets.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Seth Rosenfeld, BNP. A couple of questions, please on the loan product market. Obviously, we've seen significant decline in bar prices over the last several months, the metal's is going to be holding much better and we were another other products and for
componenttext: Seth Rosenfeld, BNP. A couple of questions, please on the loan product market. Obviously, we've seen significant decline in bar prices over the last several months, the metal's is going to be holding much better and we were another other products and for sheet. Can you comment a bit about what you see is driving this relative outperformance for long products have sustainable that it's going to be 2020? You already commented a bit on the demand side for broader supply demand perspective. Then separately, as you are nearing or beginning to ramp-up to Nour your micro bills, what's your thought on the supply-demand balance to be in the region right now there's been some news in recent weeks about your closest competitor's is shutting down one of their domestic we bar EAX. Do you think that the market stomach increase capacity or will other higher cost mills be pushed out in the coming year?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Let me start with your first question in talking about our loan products and the metal margins perform better than some of our other flat-rolled products. So clearly, the demand in our loan price is better. There was a less of a destocking issue with our
componenttext:
Let me start with your first question in talking about our loan products and the metal margins perform better than some of our other flat-rolled products. So clearly, the demand in our loan price is better. There was a less of a destocking issue with our loan products particularly when you talk about rebar, being less of an issue with rebar then we did in our sheet products on our plate products, a little bit in merchant and not significantly more. So demand was strong, overstory have imploded to the level that is in our products. Last year, lot of our loan products obviously going to construction. And construction has been relatively strong, lot of our loan products merchant and we are going to a downstream businesses. Jim mentioned in this comment internally, we're shipping about 20% of our steel products downstream. A lot of that is loan products going into our building systems in particular [indiscernible] operations. And they have been strong kicks all of those kind of lead into that. Now having said all of that, when you talk about the loan products and we talk about structural certainly the infrastructure build will continue to help with us with that -- continue to encourage the administration to get going on something that's badly needed in this country will bust infrastructure build.
So that's a little bit about the loan products. Now in terms of the comment or your question about micro mills regionally and the demand or the supply/demand ratio in the areas where we're building them, we still feel very good about that. We talked about in the past about the regional nature of these microbials. We're not going to comment on any of our competitors shutting down or anything like that. We believe that the 2 things that are going to really give us on advantage with the microbials our right in the heart of the marketplace. We've got great scrap availability for those mills. The design of the mills provide a extremely low cost structure, highly efficient, close to the supply of the raw material and close to the marketplace. Those are things that we feel make us very successful. Dave, we would add something?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: If we would comment for some of the competition shutting down, I would correct you. It's on empty product that's exiting the market, not the rebar.
componenttext: If we would comment for some of the competition shutting down, I would correct you. It's on empty product that's exiting the market, not the rebar.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: I think this may be John's last conference call. So I want to wish you well on your next chapter. Wanted to ask a little bit more about the CapEx change because even up until last conference call, you were saying it will be heavily weighted in the second
componenttext: I think this may be John's last conference call. So I want to wish you well on your next chapter. Wanted to ask a little bit more about the CapEx change because even up until last conference call, you were saying it will be heavily weighted in the second half. So is there something changed? And I know you say it's timing. But this thus mean that you're pushing more CapEx into next year? Can you give us a little more thoughts into next year? And if conditions remain somewhat sluggish, could you rethink some of the CapEx in the projects?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we rely a lot on the divisions to help us forecast when CapEx is going to happen and there's a lot of variables go into spending money, capital projects. Begins with permitting, there's visionary design products, there's continues process, there's
componenttext: Yes. So we rely a lot on the divisions to help us forecast when CapEx is going to happen and there's a lot of variables go into spending money, capital projects. Begins with permitting, there's visionary design products, there's continues process, there's lead times in getting equipment delivered and there's installation and until products are whether effecting. So until things are delivered whether it's a service for a product to the site, we can't actually counter this CapEx and paid forward. So some things behind what we hope to accomplish this year. But by enlarge, we still expect the dates we committed to in terms of start facilities. We're probably a little bit more conservative at our commitment for start-up dates than we are on the CapEx spending side. And yes, we will spend some money that we plan to spend this year next year. So in January, we'll come out and give you budget for 2020. But I expect it to be notably higher than what we're actually going to spend in 2019. Partly because of the carryover from 2019.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: I do want to make a comment on the second part of that question. I want to be really emphatic about this, okay? Listen. We're not reacting to any changes in the market. We're in a cyclical business. We don't react. We don't change our strategic plan based
componenttext: I do want to make a comment on the second part of that question. I want to be really emphatic about this, okay? Listen. We're not reacting to any changes in the market. We're in a cyclical business. We don't react. We don't change our strategic plan based upon changes in the marketplace. In fact, if anything, we will -- it's just be the opposite of what you say. We tend to invest more and grow our focus on growing our company during the downturns. It's always been our philosophy. We invest during the downturns to come back into the upturn stronger. We always talk about having higher highs and higher lows Excel want to be really clear about this. It ogt nothing to do with the change in the market dynamics at this time. We don't react. Our strategic plan is built for the long-term. We will react short-term changes in the market. Do not impact our strategic initiatives.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: John, I agree with everything. The other thing I'd add is just to understand our markets and where we serve them. We listen to our customers and where they need us to be not just today but for the long-term to provide a competitive differentiated value pr
componenttext: John, I agree with everything. The other thing I'd add is just to understand our markets and where we serve them. We listen to our customers and where they need us to be not just today but for the long-term to provide a competitive differentiated value proposition and that's really where our investments come. So to John's point, if we got but every shift in the market, I'm not sure we'll be the industry leader in the steel making industry in the North America that we are today.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just build on that, Timna. But certain if we didn't invest and grow our company during the last recession, we would not have seen the record year that we have in 2018. So it's the work that we do during those downturns that allow us to have the record yea
componenttext: Just build on that, Timna. But certain if we didn't invest and grow our company during the last recession, we would not have seen the record year that we have in 2018. So it's the work that we do during those downturns that allow us to have the record years and will continue to do that.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: So not changing your strategic view. So you don't change your strategic view given market conditions but. Just commercially and just looking at volumes I'm still kind of in shock when I look at the year-over-year trends if we kind of continue the recent v
componenttext:
So not changing your strategic view. So you don't change your strategic view given market conditions but. Just commercially and just looking at volumes I'm still kind of in shock when I look at the year-over-year trends if we kind of continue the recent volume trends and loan products. And across the board, I mean volumes are pretty significantly down. 
Just wondering seasonally things improve. I get it. But even on an annualized basis, is there anything you can help us high-level to understand that could explain reasons for a shift upward in bar structural plate just because it has been such a dramatic drop from 2018 and even from 2017 to be fair. So just wondering if there's a commercial shifting you've made to may be shipped less in a softer market? Is there a reason that these volumes can rebound or how do we think about it?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: No. It has -- we made no commercial decision to change our sales or shipping strategy based upon the conditions in the marketplace not at all. I want to be clear about that. We've talked a lot about the destocking and restocking that we've gone through
componenttext:
No. It has -- we made no commercial decision to change our sales or shipping strategy based upon the conditions in the marketplace not at all. I want to be clear about that. 
We've talked a lot about the destocking and restocking that we've gone through and most of our discussions are focused on the server center industry. But bear in mind that of course, all of our products, we saw this issue of over stalking at the end of 2018 also in the downstream business, downstream customers. 
You talk about some of the flat products and on the plate products. Some of our large equipment manufacturing customers. I don't want to name any specifically. But we know for a fact that they are inventory is up, there inventories are up at that plant site and the dealers and even in some stores location. So it's primarily -- we still feel very strongly. it's primarily an issue of stalking and destocking. We think that if you look at your domain, we think demand is somewhat down by 3% or 4%. Certainly, the volumes do not reflect that, more significant than that. So we still believe strongly that was looking at the issue of stalking and destocking that will continue to work our way through. We will come through this and we'll get back to our normalized in right levels and normalized booking and shipping levels.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019

componenttext: In terms of the rebar investment at Marian, I think Liane was discussing that. I know it's an upgrade specifically to your rolling mill. Curious if that immediate any of your productivity or how that will upgrades are taking place?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: I'll -- let me kick it off now and my turn over to Dave or to Leon to add to it. But the short answer is no, okay? the team has done an outstanding job of making the modifications to improve our quality and our efficiency and productivity at those mills w
componenttext:
I'll -- let me kick it off now and my turn over to Dave or to Leon to add to it. But the short answer is no, okay? the team has done an outstanding job of making the modifications to improve our quality and our efficiency and productivity at those mills while at the same time, continuing to provide quality products to our customers. 
The other point that I would make and again, thanking the team. We had a great safety record during this rebuild. And whenever you have modifying an existing mill and continuing to run that mill while you're making those improvements to it, it can be challenging from a safety perspective. The team did an outstanding job of getting the project done on time, on budget and most importantly, without any major accidents so I thank you for that. Anything that you want to add, Dave?

componenttext:
Great. Appreciate tat. A question on the materials segment. A lot of headwinds right now, they seemed to be numerous, curious in your mind, which out of these headwinds that you're seeing right now are transitory and maybe, which are structural? We certainly didn't expect to see the results as negative as they were in the third quarter and getting more negative. 
And then just as a subquestion. When did the DRI investments that you're making come to a conclusion? And the may to remind us of the magnitude of those investments.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: SO a bunch of questions there. Let me start with the end then I'll work my way back towards the project that I will our Louisiana plant will wrap up a schedule to wrap up on November 14. And we've looked like -- at this point, we believe we're on time, we
componenttext:
SO a bunch of questions there. Let me start with the end then I'll work my way back towards the project that I will our Louisiana plant will wrap up a schedule to wrap up on November 14. And we've looked like -- at this point, we believe we're on time, we believe we're on schedule and -- excuse me, on budget. So things are looking pretty good at Louisiana. Just as a reminder, there was 2 major things that we're attacking all together 2 major ones. One is in the handling, how we manage the feeding of the raw material storage and feeding into the furnace. And that's gone particularly well. We think that can have a major impact on the productivity of that operation and we also think we placed the lining in the vessel. 
And as you might recall, we have had numerous major problems with the process and of course, we have basically replacing the entire process within the design that we have great feel of confidence. And all of these changes were done to increase the productivity, reduced our cost in that operation. It's called project 8,000 for a reason. Reason being that we want to be able to get out to 8,000 hours of operation. We believe that we'll be able to accomplish that next year. If we do -- and let me rephrase that, when we do, okay, we'll have the result of about 2.2 metric tons of production. 2.2 million metric tons our drove that operation, which will put in terms of hours of operation on par with our Trinidad facility, which suggest under 8,000 hours of operation last year. So I don't remember what was a total cost of the project that was combined?

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: On the timing of these things. In terms of what's temporary, what's permanent, obviously, we'll get the cost benefit from these investments, we are meant taking cost penalty and pre-operating startup cost in the third quarter related to these investments
componenttext: On the timing of these things. In terms of what's temporary, what's permanent, obviously, we'll get the cost benefit from these investments, we are meant taking cost penalty and pre-operating startup cost in the third quarter related to these investments and then that will be done after the fourth quarter. But the part where our margins are compressed in both the DRI business and in the scrap business, that's part of the cycle of the business when prices are low for pig iron, we have to sell DRI to ourselves in low price. And if iron ore prices don't go down enough, it putjs a squeeze in the margins. So that's a cyclical business like all of our businesses and right now, it feels like it's at the bottom of the cycle. It means it gets better.

headline: Nucor Corporation, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 22, 2019
componenttextpreview: And remember, it's kind of a hedge, right? This is kind of a good news bad news thing when we talk about our raw material business struggling. What it means is, as Tim pointed out, it means that scrap is at a low level. Pig iron is at a low level and we c
componenttext: And remember, it's kind of a hedge, right? This is kind of a good news bad news thing when we talk about our raw material business struggling. What it means is, as Tim pointed out, it means that scrap is at a low level. Pig iron is at a low level and we consume amount of move scrap and a tremendous amount of pig iron. So it's a good news, bad news situation. It's kind of -- when we built this, we talked about it being a hedging operation and build particular to -- to put kind of put -- help put a cap on the upward movement of scrap particularly during really good markets. And we saw that happen in 2018 and accomplish what was meant to accomplish in 2018.
